did.head: Collection Summary
did.unittitle:
Linda Pershing "Ribbon around the Pentagon" collection
1984-2018
1985-1989
did.physdesc: 5 photographic prints : black-and-white ; 4 x 5 in., 5 x 7 in.

corpname.part: American Folklife Center, Library of Congress

did.abstract: Collection of ethnographic research data about Justine Merritt's "Ribbon around the Pentagon" project and subsequent related events. Includes several original Ribbon panels, audio interviews with participants, photographs of various Ribbon project events, video of lectures and documentaries, questionnaire responses, and signed copies of publications written by the collector.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: All Ribbon panels, many photographs, and some documents in the collection were created by Ribbon project panel makers, primarily in the United States, between 1984 and 1989. Linda Pershing began collecting these materials from panel makers and Ribbon project founding officers in 1985 or 1986, and they remained in her possession until their donation to the American Folklife Center in 2018. Linda Pershing created all audio recordings, some photographs, and some documents, which remained in her possession until their donation in 2018.

accruals.head: Accruals
accruals.p: Additional Ribbon panels may be accrued in the future.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The Linda Pershing "Ribbon around the Pentagon" collection was processed by Farrah Cundiff in 2021 and 2022.

p.ref: The Ribbon Records (Mss 043), Texas Woman's University

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: Duplication of collection materials may be governed by copyright and other restrictions.

Materials in the collection were generated by various creators. Some materials are copies. Known creators are named in this finding aid whenever possible. Materials with no creator attribution require further research to determine rights and origin.
The public may use materials created by Linda Pershing, except that the public may not use them for personal gain or to make a profit.

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p:
The Linda Pershing "Ribbon around the Pentagon" collection is open to research. To request materials, please contact the Folklife Reading Room at
https://hdl.loc.gov/loc.afc/folklife.contact
Certain restrictions to use or copying of materials may apply.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: [item, date, container number], Linda Pershing "Ribbon around the Pentagon" collection (AFC 2018/007), American Folklife Center, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Linda Pershing is a folklorist with a focus on women's experiences and feminist theory, peace and justice activism, feminist pedagogy, folklore studies, and the politics of culture.

For six years following the "Ribbon around the Pentagon" event which took place in the summer of 1985, Pershing traveled around the country to interview Ribbon project participants at their homes, photograph Ribbon panels, and collect qualitative research data about the project. She wrote about her ethnographic research of the Ribbon project in her essay
Peace Work out of Piecework: Feminist Needlework Metaphors and the Ribbon around the Pentagon
(1993) and in her books
Sew to Speak: The Fabric Art of Mary Milne
(1995) and
The Ribbon around the Pentagon: Peace by Piecemakers
(1996).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The "Ribbon around the Pentagon" ceremony was a grass-roots public art event and anti-nuclear peace demonstration which took place in Washington, D.C., on August 4, 1985 (the weekend before the 40th anniversary of the atomic bombing of Hiroshima, Japan). Activists protesting nuclear arms created hand-made fabric panels which depicted the things that would be lost in the event of a nuclear disaster. Panels showcased a variety of fiber arts including embroidery, quilting, garment sewing, fabric painting, knitting, weaving, appliqué, and needlework. The panels were tied together to form a 15-mile long "Ribbon," and the Ribbon was wrapped around the Pentagon, the Capitol, and the Lincoln and Washington Memorials by demonstrators holding the panels they created.

The collection primarily consists of the opinions of participants and the imagery of Ribbon panels. Collection materials include several original Ribbon panels, photographs of Ribbon panels, photographs of events which took place after the original 1985 demonstration, video of lectures and documentaries, audio interviews with project founders and participants, and questionnaire responses. All Ribbon panels, most documents, and many photographs in the collection were created by Ribbon project participants, primarily in the United States, between 1984 and 1989. All audio recordings and many photographs were created by Linda Pershing between 1985 and 1989.
The materials in this collection refer to the original ceremony and related activities which took place from 1984 to 1989 as "the Ribbon project."

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Linda Pershing "Ribbon around the Pentagon" collection is organized into five series:

Two subjects stand out due to the depth of documentation and their prominence in Linda Pershing's publications: Ribbon project founder Justine Merritt; and project participant Mary Milne. Most materials related to these subjects have been arranged in distinct groupings for ease of reference.
Photographs are listed with the date they were taken; when that is unknown, the photograph development or copy date is listed.

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

persname.part: Hollis, Susan T., Feminist theory and the study of folklore. 1993.
Merritt, Justine, 1924-2009. Cup of cool water.

did.unittitle:
Series 1: Justine Merritt,
1984-1989

scopecontent.p:
Taped interviews and lectures, photos, an original textile Ribbon panel, and a documentary video about Justine Merritt, the founder of the Ribbon project. Much of Linda Pershing's book
The Ribbon around the Pentagon: Peace by Piecemakers
(1996) focused on Justine Merritt and included references to the materials in this series. The series combines tapes recorded by Linda Pershing with photos and videos she collected from other sources. The Ribbon panel is an original work created by Justine Merritt.

Ribbon panels by Justine Merritt

Ribbon panel, "Names,"
circa 1985

scopecontent.p: Linda Pershing's description: "Fourth 'names' panel with names of people she would hate to lose in a nuclear war, embroidered. Many were people she met as she traveled the U.S. promoting the project. Justine said that she left the bottom empty to symbolize the people who would come into her life in the future. See p. 90 in Pershing's book."

Series 2: Mary Milne,
1987-1990

scopecontent.p:
Taped interviews, photos, and a documentary video about Mary Milne, a prolific participant of the Ribbon project and the subject of Linda Pershing's book
Sew to Speak: The Fabric Art of Mary Milne
. The series consists primarily of audiotapes and photographs created by Linda Pershing. The video documentary was produced by Mary Milne.

did.unittitle:
Series 3: Other Ribbon project participants,
1984-1989

scopecontent.p:
Taped interviews, photographs of events, photographs of Ribbon panels, original textile Ribbon panels, documentary videos, study data about the Ribbon project, and photo submissions to a book publisher. This series combines audiotapes recorded by Linda Pershing with photographs, video recordings, study data, and book submissions that she collected from other sources. The materials in this series are referenced throughout Linda Pershing's book,
The Ribbon around the Pentagon: Peace by Piecemakers
(1996). Most materials about Justine Merritt and Mary Milne have been removed to separate series above for ease of use, except for the Subseries "Ribbon events" which depicts all participants including Merritt and Milne.

Ribbon panels

Ribbon panel, "Organdy apron,"
before August 1985

scopecontent.p: Linda Pershing's description: "Lucile (spelled with one 'L') Miller, Justine Merritt's mother, organdy apron panel, applique, Denver, CO. Lucile said in an interview with Linda Pershing that the apron represented the many years she was a homemaker and mother, roles that she valued. See pp. 198-9 in Pershing's book."

did.unittitle:
Ribbon panel, "Madre de los Oprimidos,"
before August 1985
did.physdesc: 1 textile (18 x 45 in.; embroidery and appliqué)

name.part: Made by Sister Maria Louisa Valdez

scopecontent.p: Linda Pershing's description: "Sister Maria Louisa Valdez, OLVM, Mora, NM. Madre de los Oprimidos, Ayúdanos a Alcanzar le Libertad Perdida (Mother of the Oppressed, Help Us Restore or Reclaim Lost Liberty), embroidered and applique. The Mexican legend of the Our Lady of Guadalupe appearing to Juan Diego. See p. 128 in Pershing's book."

did.unittitle:
Ribbon panel, "My Dog,"
before August 1985

scopecontent.p: Linda Pershing's description: "My Dog. Presumably painted by a child. No name or place or date. (Is the dog in the blue hillside or water?)."

did.unittitle:
Ribbon panel, "Dancing lobsters,"
before August 1985

scopecontent.p: Linda Pershing's description: "Penelope Day, Nantucket, MA. Dancing lobsters, knitted or woven. Inscription on the back: 'I live in a beautiful parts of the country, on the island of Nantucket, thirty miles out at sea. I felt that my piece should be representative of something native to Nantucket and the natural beauty and special conditions that exist here as they don't anywhere else on Earth. I wanted to do something for children, something fun. They are our future and it is too terrible to live without hope for tomorrow. --Penelope Day.' See pp. 126-7 of Pershing's book."

did.unittitle:
Ribbon panel, "Hot air balloons and flowers,"
before August 1985

name.part: Made by Sister Madeleine J. Perkins

scopecontent.p: Linda Pershing's description: "Sister Madeleine J. Perkins, RSM, Chicago, IL. Hot air balloons and flowers. Inscription on the back: 'Hot air balloons - excitement, fun, color, freedom; Flowers - nature, beauty, creation, sweet scents; People to enjoy it all!; O God, help us to work for world peace!!'"

did.unittitle:
Ribbon panel, "Peace Sign and Spirit Mask,"
before August 1985

scopecontent.p: Linda Pershing's description: "Fred Janvrin ... Anchorage, Alaska. Peace Sign and Spirit Mask. Inscription on the back: ... A peace sign trying to be a Spirit Mask. This piece reflects my fondness for Alaskan Native art and spirit masks in particular with their feathers blowing in the wind. Also marked: 'P.M. 2 of 21,' and 'NRC 44.'"

did.unittitle:
Ribbon panel, "Weaving is Peaceful,"
before August 1985

scopecontent.p: Linda Pershing's description: "Kerstin Tribby, Ithaca, NY. Weaving is Peaceful, woven sampler."

did.unittitle:
Ribbon panel, "Constellations,"
March 8, 1985
did.physdesc: 1 textile (18 1/4 x 36 3/4 in.; embroidery, appliqué, and quilting)

name.part: Made by Jane Van De Bogart

scopecontent.p: Linda Pershing's description: "Jane Van De Bogart, 3-8-85, Woodstock, NY. Constellations. Embroidered, applique, and quilted. Written on the back: 'The night sky has been an endless source of wonder...of worlds beyond me...of something to aspire higher for...of fascination.' Also written on the back: 'Jane Van De Bogart April 1985.'"

did.unittitle:
Copies of study data collected by Gabriella Miller and Carol Cockrell,
1985

name.part: Designed by Gabriella Miller and Carol Cockrell

scopecontent.p:
Each folder contains the compiled responses to one question from a questionnaire created by Texas Woman's University researchers Gabriella Miller and Carol Cockrell. The researchers had the questionnaire printed in a 1985 issue of
Ribbon Newsletter
, and participants joined the study by returning their responses in the mail. Participants are anonymized as numbers 1-805.

Statements and photos submitted to Lark Books

scopecontent.p:
A selection of 35mm slides and submission forms sent to the publisher Lark Books by Ribbon panel makers, for inclusion in the book
The Ribbon: A Celebration of Life
(1985).

circa January to May 17, 1985

Series 4: Research materials,
1985-1995

scopecontent.p: Original output from Linda Pershing's research. This series includes photographs originally collected from other sources but curated by Linda Pershing for her teaching lectures. Includes copies of Linda Pershing's scholarly publications on the Ribbon project. Also includes one cleaning microcassette.

Series 5: Donation notes,
2018

scopecontent.p: Notes written by Linda Pershing at the time of the collection's donation to the American Folklife Center at the Library of Congress. The notes were interspersed with materials as labels. The information from the notes has been incorporated into this finding aid.

did.unittitle:
Linda Pershing's donation notes,
circa May 14, 2018
